Message.Title: Short INTC like there's no tomorrow. Sybil here's your chance.
Message.Msg: INTC is the biggest loser in the collapse of the solid state drives market. Consumers feel betrayed. They were "told" that because solid state drives consist of memory with far fewer mechanical, moving parts than hard disk drives, they will last forever. They got wiser and finding out that that ain't so. The memory used in these devices have limits as to how many times they can be written. Consumers have gone into a boycott. So many solid state drives manufacturers have been forced to slash prices (cutting in half) and they're still not moving well. These days, you can often find 240 GB solid state drives for about $120-130 on sale. Here's one of Intel's model (from Radio Shack): IntelÂ® 520 Series 240GB SSD $279.99 This feels like the demise of Sun Micro Systems. Their network gear was too expensive compared to competitors.

Topic.Title: another day another transfer of AAPL stock $ to AMZN stock

Message.Msg: shows you the limitied fear of the momemtum traders here to risk if they sell off AAPL, which on a #$%$ basis has huge cash, dividends, and reasonable multiple even if it's growth takes a hit, while recommending a further widening in valuation metrics by chasing AMZN here: up to 320 times last 4 qtrs earnings, no dividends, a paltry % of cash reserves of AAPL. This is the 4th qtr mindset here? In other words, he's saying the bubbles will chased while selling the reasonable values , and widening the gap to more ludicrous levels. As far a GOOG, while it doesn't have a outlandish valuation, it's not cheap after a 200 point run from August, and Now get the Cramer stamp of aproval to the "masses." It's amazing how Cramer plays these RSI games over and over: what has been working keep buying games. Sometimes that method can run into trouble for him: like in year 2000 in recommending Nortel and other stocks that had outlandish valuations. He's throwing risk to the wind here with this timing. The market has for a very long shown no fear to the point where the players forget about what they are buying things at.

Message.Msg: well we can do the math on the earings expecatations on that basis here: Cramer expects 2.30 area earnings: what's funny is at a much lower stock price, AMZN was making $2,53 peak earnings and then they turned down. The analysts , who all had AMZN earnings growing way past there, started to change their story that the downturn was due to "investing" in expansion. Now that puts into question the "capitalized items" of that expansion as most of those costs would be and should not have affected such a turndown in earnings. Never focused on. Never has mattered. Just the foward earnings growth here on an 82 cents lower base than the $2.53 peak. Thus, the 110 plus multiple on foward earnings and over 300 on backward. Earnings havn't mattered for AMZN like almost for all other companies for so long now.

The past few years have been scam investment. The next few will be a return to investment while the MOMO boys get put permanently out of business...

Message.Title: Kindle Fire is losing money business model.
Message.Msg: Amazon kindle fire sell at or below the cost. Amazon wishful dream is to get more revenue from selling its contents. However, most of people buy Kindle Fire are price sensitive consumers. They will only purchase the good deal from Amazon. This mean Amazon will make much smaller profit margin from overall tablet+content business model. The return of investment ratio definitely is not good. Apple iPad mini will be released soon. Google/Asus may have some update for its nexus 7. B&N also will release higher resolution 7" tablet. The competition is really getting tougher. Amazon will have to cut price further in order to move the inventory. Eventually, the Kindle Fire business will turn to losing money business.

Topic.Title: incredible resilience of INTC.

Message.Msg: Sybs: 1) Cannot really argue with that. 2) Let's be a little more specific. It will absolutely decline in real terms. The Fed and global central bank put is simply trying to make it a steady and not destabilizing drop. I think they will have succeeded. Having said that, it is still uncertain as to whether the market will decline in nominal terms (although for the overwhelming majority of companies WS has been pushing people into are highly likely to decline in nominal terms as well). Certain companies, like INTC, are exceptionally well positioned to succeed and could skyrocket in the future in some relatively probable scenarios. Further, INTC has firm dividend support that will grow in nominal terms... 3) I've learned how "they" play the game and how to profit from it on different timescales. But, I do discourage others from playing, especially ST, unless they have enough capital to move the market as many of the algo option scalping players do....

Topic.Title: Guess the open

Message.Msg: They ought to gap down are start triggering all the stop losses on the long side. We all know they've spent the last few months hunting them on the short side... Gaping down over the 50 day would be nice... It will be fun the see all the longs tested for awhile. The big institutional longs have no need to pay up for anything. They'll do exactly what they are doing with INTC right now -- test to see where the real buying pressure is. In the meanwhile, traders will pop in for a squeeze here and there, at which time I will increase my positions... Sybs, you gotta give me some cred for predicting that all out assault on Amazon. Did you see WalMart is testing same day delivery? I could rehash all of the competitive moves against Amazon, but it's getting pretty long. BN, TGT, BBY, WMT, GOOG, AAPL, ORCL.... Amazon is spending a TON on TV's commercials too (gotta combat all those retail stores promoting competitive offerings with actual human beings making the case)...

Topic.Title: incredible resilience of INTC.

Message.Msg: Sybs, True about the shorting. I wasn't aware of the ability to short back in 2001, wish I did. But your wrong about all stocks. As the markets collapse, long only funds need to bury money somewhere. Preferably stocks that pay a dividend, has some growth and isn't losing 10% a week. Once they find those stocks other money that has to stay invested will pile into it. Kinda like how these growth stocks all become momo stocks because there are not enough growth stocks for all the Fed printed money. Shorting will probably be the way to go but if you want a hedge, a few good long stocks isn't a bad idea. Tech holding INTC from 22 to 44, would be like you shorting AMZN from 260 to 130. I think Tech hits his mark first...even in a down market. - PJ p.s. It could of been NASDAQ6000. At least Gee posts his trades real time.
